#Text=VIII
#Text=In America we have been bringing up our women like men , and treating them like children .
#Text=They have active minds with nothing to act upon .
#Text=Thus they are driven to think chiefly about themselves .
#Text=With Jane Hastings , self-centering took the form of self-analysis most of the time .
#Text=She was intensely interested in what she regarded as the new development of her character .
#Text=This definite and apparently final decision for the narrow and the ungenerous .
#Text=In fact , it was no new development , but simply a revelation to herself of her own real character .
#Text=She was seeing at last the genuine Jane Hastings , inevitable product of a certain heredity in a certain environment .
#Text=The high thinking and talking , the idealistic aspiration were pose and pretense .
#Text=Jane Hastings was a selfish , self-absorbed person , ready to do almost any base thing to gain her ends , ready to hate to the uttermost any one who stood between her and her object .

#Text=" I 'm certainly not a lovely person -- not a lovable person , " thought she , with that gentle tolerance wherewith we regard our ownselves , whether in the dress of pretense or in the undress of deformed humanness . "

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=Still -- I am what I am , and I 've got to make the best of it .

column1: #Text=" It could n't harm anybody . "
#Text=" You must n't touch it , popsy , " said Jane .
#Text=She unthinkingly spoke a little too commandingly .
#Text=Her father , in a perverse and reckless mood , took Martha 's advice .
#Text=An hour later Dr. Charlton was summoned , and had he not arrived promptly -- --
#Text=" Another fifteen or twenty minutes , " said he to the old man when he had him out of immediate danger , " and I 'd have had nothing to do but sign a certificate of natural death . "
#Text=" Murder would have been nearer the truth , " said Martin feebly .
#Text=" That there fool Martha ! "
#Text=" Come out from behind that petticoat ! " cried Charlton .

#Text=" Did n't I spend the best part of three days in giving you the correct ideas as to health and disease -- in showing you that ALL disease comes from indigestion -- ALL disease , from falling hair and sore eyes to weak ankles and corns ?

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= Do n't hit a man when he 's down , " groaned Hastings .

column1: #Text=" If I do n't , you 'll do the same idiotic trick again when I get you up -- if I get you up . "
#Text=Hastings looked quickly at him .
#Text=This was the first time Charlton had ever expressed a doubt about his living .
#Text=" Do you mean that ? " he said hoarsely .
#Text=" Or are you just trying to scare me ? "
#Text=" Both , " said Charlton .
#Text=" I 'll do my best , but I ca n't promise .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= I 'll never do it again , " said Hastings , pleading , but smiling , too -- Charlton 's way of talking delighted him .

column1: #Text=" You think this is a joke , " said Charlton , shaking his bullet head .
#Text=" Have you any affairs to settle ?

#Text=If you have , send for your lawyer in the morning .

column1: #Text=" You know you will pull me through . "
#Text=" I 'll do my best , " said Charlton .
#Text=" I promise nothing .

#Text=I 'm serious about the lawyer .

#Text= I do n't want no lawyer hanging round my bed , " growled the old man .

column1: #Text=" It 'd kill me .

#Text=And there 's Jinny and Marthy and the boy -- share and share alike .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Well -- you 're in no immediate danger .

_	_	_	_

#Text= Wait till I get to sleep . "

column1: #Text=" You 'll be asleep as soon as the light 's down .
